html.p: Definition. An elementary matrix is a square matrix of one of three types.

div.h4: Elementary Matrix of the First Type
div.div:
An elementary matrix of the first type is one obtained from the identity matrix by changing the diagonal entry in the [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline]th row and column to a number [mathjaxinline]c[/mathjaxinline], where [mathjaxinline]c \ne 0[/mathjaxinline]:
[mathjax]E_1 = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccccc} 1 & & & & & & \\ & \ddots & & & & & \\ & & 1& & & & \\ & & & c & & & \\ & & & & 1 & & \\ & & & & & \ddots & \\ & & & & & & 1 \end{array} \right].[/mathjax] Multiplying a matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] by [mathjaxinline]E_1[/mathjaxinline] (where [mathjaxinline]E_1[/mathjaxinline] is on the left) has the same effect as scaling row [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline] of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] by the scalar [mathjaxinline]c[/mathjaxinline].

div.h4: Elementary Matrix of the Second Type
div.div:
An elementary matrix of the second type is one obtained from the identity matrix by changing the non-diagonal entry in the [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline]th row and [mathjaxinline]j[/mathjaxinline]th column ([mathjaxinline]i\ne j[/mathjaxinline]) to a number [mathjaxinline]c \ne 0[/mathjaxinline]:
[mathjax]E_2 = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccccc} 1 & & & & & & \\ & \ddots & & & & & \\ & & 1& & & & \\ & & & \ddots & & & \\ & & c & & 1 & & \\ & & & & & \ddots & \\ & & & & & & 1 \end{array} \right].[/mathjax] Multiplying a matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] by [mathjaxinline]E_2[/mathjaxinline] (where [mathjaxinline]E_2[/mathjaxinline] is on the left) has the same effect as adding [mathjaxinline]c[/mathjaxinline] times the [mathjaxinline]j[/mathjaxinline]th row of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] to row [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline].

div.h4: Elementary Matrix of the Third Type
div.div:
An elementary matrix of the third type is one obtained from the identity matrix by changing the [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline]th and [mathjaxinline]j[/mathjaxinline]th diagonal entries to 0, and changing the entries in the [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline]th row and [mathjaxinline]j[/mathjaxinline]th column, and the [mathjaxinline]j[/mathjaxinline]th row and [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline]th column, to 1:
[mathjax]E_3 = \left[ \begin{array}{ccccccccccc} 1 & & & & & & & & & & \\ & \ddots & & & & & & & & & \\ & & 1& & & & & & & & \\ & & & 0 & & & & 1 & & & \\ & & & & 1 & & & & & & \\ & & & & & \ddots & & & & & \\ & & & & & & 1 & & & & \\ & & & 1 & & & & 0 & & & \\ & & & & & & & & 1 & & \\ & & & & & & & & & \ddots & \\ & & & & & & & & & & 1 \end{array} \right].[/mathjax] Multiplying a matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] by [mathjaxinline]E_3[/mathjaxinline] (where [mathjaxinline]E_3[/mathjaxinline] is on the left) has the same effect as swapping the [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline]th and [mathjaxinline]j[/mathjaxinline]th rows of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline].
